news_header: Austria's central parties are close to forming a coalition government, ending a five-month wait after prolonged negotiations.
news_text: After nearly five months of negotiations, Austria's largest central parties, the Conservative People's Party (ÖVP), the Social Democrats (SPÖ), and the Liberal Neos, are optimistic about forming a coalition government without the extreme right. This follows the right-wing Freedom Party (FPÖ) winning 29% in the September elections. Previous attempts to form a government involving the FPÖ failed, leading to renewed discussions among the central parties. If successful, this coalition would mark Austria's first three-party government since 1949, concluding the longest government negotiations in the country since World War II.
